description: Fake sites mimicking The North Face, like northfaceblackfriday.shop, are offering bogus Black Friday deals. Entering your credit card info sends it directly to scammers.
how to spot it: Always verify the URL – legitimate sites use the official domain with no typos or unusual extensions. Extremely steep discounts and urgent messages are red flags.

description: Instagram ads offer Nike sneakers at 80% off via cloned sites mimicking the official store. Buyers risk receiving knock-offs and exposing their payment info.
how to spot it: Double-check the Instagram profile and website URL – official Nike promotions always link to nike.com. If the deal is dramatically below market value, it is likely a scam.

description: Scam emails claim Amazon orders are on hold due to account issues and link to fake login pages. These pages capture your credentials as soon as you sign in.
how to spot it: Examine the sender’s email address – authentic Amazon emails come exclusively from @amazon.com. When in doubt, type amazon.com directly into your browser.

description: Walmart gift card giveaways on Facebook direct users to fraudulent survey sites. They collect personal data and fees, but no gift card follows.
how to spot it: Legitimate Walmart promotions are verified on official channels. If a giveaway sounds excessively generous or requires a fee, it is a red flag.

description: Chase text alert scams warn of unusual account activity and prompt clicks on a counterfeit login page. This page captures your credentials.
how to spot it: Chase texts come only from verified short codes. If you receive such an alert, enter the official website manually or use the Chase app.

description: Scammers impersonate Bank of America’s fraud team, calling and claiming your account is at risk. They urge you to transfer funds to a ‘safe’ account they control.
how to spot it: Bank of America will never pressure you to move funds over the phone. Hang up and call the official customer service number to verify.

description: Fake Wells Fargo emails claim your account is locked and urge you to click to restore access. Instead, the link captures your data.
how to spot it: Check the sender’s email – official messages come from an @wellsfargo.com address. If a link seems suspicious, log in directly through the official website.

description: PayPal alert scams warn of pending account limitations via email. The included links lead to fake login pages that capture your credentials.
how to spot it: Real PayPal emails address you by name and come from secure addresses. Instead of clicking links, navigate directly to PayPal by typing the URL.

description: Fake Microsoft pop-ups warn that your system is infected and urge you to call support. Calling installs remote access software that compromises your device.
how to spot it: Legitimate Microsoft alerts come from the operating system or official update channels. If a pop-up forces you to call an unknown number, close it and run a trusted antivirus scan.

description: Apple support scammers call, claiming iCloud accounts are compromised. They urge you to install fake security apps or buy Apple gift cards for recovery.
how to spot it: Apple will never call unsolicited or request gift card payments. Hang up immediately and call Apple Support using the official number.

description: On LinkedIn, scammers posing as Google recruiters offer quick job placements. They conduct brief online interviews and request personal details.
how to spot it: Google’s hiring process is thorough and never uses casual messages to finalize offers. Verify recruiter identities through Google’s official careers page.

description: Costco HR text scams offer work-from-home customer service roles but then demand fees for training or shipping. The scammers disappear after taking your money.
how to spot it: Costco never recruits through random texts or asks for upfront fees. Confirm job offers through official company channels on Costco’s website.

description: Scam emails targeting job seekers claim to offer Amazon remote positions, such as virtual assistant roles. They quickly ask for a training fee or banking details and then vanish.
how to spot it: Legitimate job offers from Amazon come through their official careers portal and never require upfront payments. Be wary if a work-from-home job asks for money or sensitive personal info early on.

description: On Tinder, scammers pose as U.S. Army officers deployed overseas to build trust with users. They then request funds for fake emergencies like lost wallets or urgent repairs.
how to spot it: Any financial request from someone you’ve never met is a red flag. Real military personnel will never ask for money via a dating app.

description: Scammers on Facebook Dating pose as widowed engineers on oil rigs to build trust with users. They later claim a crisis has stranded them and ask for cash.
how to spot it: If your online match avoids video calls and then asks for money, it's a red flag. Verify personal claims by requesting a live conversation before offering financial help.

description: On dating apps, scammers claim crypto success via Coinbase and push victims to invest immediately. They use fake dashboards showing rising balances to lure you in.
how to spot it: High-pressure investment pitches from new online acquaintances are a red flag. Always perform independent research and never let a budding romance override sound practices.

description: USPS text scams claim delivery delays over small unpaid fees and provide links to bogus sites. These sites steal credit card information from multiple users.
how to spot it: The U.S. Postal Service does not send texts requesting immediate payments. Use official USPS tracking tools or contact your local post office to verify any issues.

description: FedEx scam emails warn of missed deliveries and urge you to update your address via a link. The link leads to a fake site that steals your personal and financial details.
how to spot it: Inspect the sender’s email – genuine FedEx communications come from an official fedex.com address only. If an email urges immediate action, log in to FedEx using a browser to verify.

description: IRS scam calls and emails falsely claim you owe back taxes or that your refund is withheld unless you pay immediately. They pressure you to use prepaid gift cards or wire transfers and steal your sensitive info.
how to spot it: Legitimate IRS communications are sent by mail and never ask for immediate payment through electronic means. Verify by contacting the IRS directly or checking their official website.

description: Xfinity scam emails warn that a failed payment will disconnect your service and direct you to a fake login page. These pages capture your credentials and billing info.
how to spot it: Official Xfinity emails come from verified addresses and won’t pressure you for immediate action. If in doubt, log into your account directly or call customer service.
